div.head: The Mad Dog REBELLION, worm'd and muzzl'd. With some Reasons why a Personall Tre • ty with his Majesty is a • l yea why held in doubt or suspence and why never like to be, if some can withstand it.
div.p: IT is an exceeding joy, and cause of continuall thankfullnesse to God, of and for all loyall Subjects, for having the happinesse to have so much grace given them from above, as not to be Rebells; but (in bad time be it spoken) England is now, and hath beene a long time plagued with them as the Egyptians were with innum • rable Frogs, Lice, and Caterpillers, &c. As they are Englishmen they are to be loved, and pittied, but as they are Rebells they are to be abhor'd; they are to be grieved for (as B • eth • en) but they are to be opposed as the worst of Enemies: as we ought to require them to a loyall peace; so also we should desire them to be all hang'd if they continue obstinate, bloody Rebells.

Let us examine and conferre a little with our selves, could any, or all the forraigne enemies we have, ever have done this once famous and Renowned Kingdome so much mischiefe as we have done and suff • ed more then 7 yeares? These barbarous Vi • laines do know that they were never called of God, a • d they know also they were never sent by the King; they further know that by their Rebelion they have resisted God, offended the King, and ruined the Kingdome; and all this th • y have done under the pretence of Reformation, and under the colour or pretence of Gods cause, and the K • ngs honour, and their Countreys good, Kim Kam, against all Law and order of God and man: are they Kings to • use and governe? Let us know how, and by whose permission: Are they the Kings Officers, or
Ministers: it were good that they would shew their commission, if they be (as they brag and boast) called of God; we are desirous to see some signes or good tokens of it in their better behaviour, it were not amisse if they would let us know what Moses, or what Aaron either call'd, or caus'd them to rise; if for the Protestant Religion▪ we had it, and it was a glorious Church here, and an illustrious splendor to all Christian Nations, and might, and would have remained with us continually, if they (like bruit Bores) had not violently torne downe the hedges of our fruitfull and flourishing Vinyard, devoured her Grapes, rooted up her Vines, and broken downe the Walls of our peacefull Sion, whereby they have made Gods houses of Prayer the Divells dennes of Thieves. They had forgott (or else they never remembred) that Christ commanded them to flee from persecution, not to fight for Religion; but here was no persecution to flee from, or any Protestant Religion to fight for, for, we had it in quiet use, practise, and possession; the Rule of Christian • is to s • ffer as Martyrs, and not to murder as Tyrants; whereby may be plainely perceived that the Rebells, and holy, wicked, devout, ungodly Sain • s, and Army have neither folowed the Counsell of Christ, the constancy of the Martyrs, nor the peaceable known Laws of the Kingdome: these are the fruits of their faiths, this is the regard they have of their owne soules; for they hold i • no sinne to be perjured; the Citizens of London, and all other Cities, Townes, and Corporations in England all of them (who are free of any Trades) did take Oathes in this manner.

I doe sweare to be true to our Sovoraigne Lord, King James, (in whose Raigne there are many men alive, when they were bound Apprentises) but the like, and the same bond and Oath hath beene taken by two many perjur'd Rebells; since the raigne of our soveraigne Lord King Charles, and to his Lawfull heires and successors; it were good that every Citizen, Tradesman, or any Subjects whatsoever, to consider what, and to whom they have sworne, and to remember who it is that will call them to an accoumpt
for their perjury in the breach of their oathes, by an unnaturall and accurst rebellion; but it may be objected that all the Nobility and Gentry in his Majesties Dominions have taken the same Oath, and that every Member of Parliament of both Houses, Peeres and Commons have taken the said Oath, and the most of them have made such slender accoumpt of the said Oath that they have broken the said Oath, and all the Oathes of Alegeance, supremacy, fidelity, and Loyalty, in raising and making Warres again their Soveraigne, whom they are sworne to obey, and by and from whom they have and hold their honours and great estates, many of them being his Majesties owne houshold sworne servants; therefore seeing our betters have lead us (poore Citizens and Tradesmen) into perjury by our following their example, and if it do happen that we fall into perdition with them, this is like to be our best comfort, that we have right Honourable, and rich Worshipfull company and companions.

Thus hath the Devill rob'd you of your integrity, and Loyalty, which you owed to a gracious King, and you have basely bestowed all your obedience upon an imposture, a monstrous Idoll, a thing without a head, a headles thing, by fooles and knaves honoured and call'd a Parliament.

The loving Independent who would have all things in a parity or equality, no superority, no inferiority, no man in better or worse estate then another; this is a hard matter to bring to passe, but yet it may and will be done, if the Rebells do go on as they have hitherto; the businesse must be done by killing and murder (as they are old excellent at it) the fooles must kill all the wisemen, the knaves must kill all the honest men, the deformed must kill all that are handsome, the rude must kill all the eloquent, the ignorant must kill all that have knoledge, the young must kill all the old, the poore must kill all the rich, and this is the way to make all even, and lay all levell.

Thus by ambition they would raigne over all, and by Avarice they would every whit; these are our earthly mortall Lucifers, these are the aspiring Phaetons, these are they that do scorne good Counsell; for indeede there is no perswasion
where Treason masters reason; they had rather runne the hazzerd to endure the miseries of hunger, cold, halter, and Hell, then to recant, repent, or returne into the pale or compasse of obedience, wherein their whole safty consists, both in this life and in a better; yet for all that hath beene, or can be written or said, they are inwardly bent against Peace, ar a Personalll thing call'd a Treaty: It would be accounted a strange boldnesse, and arrogancy in a mans heele to presume (not onely to Counsell but command his Head) it is Treason to vilifie the King in words or writing, and good King Charles hath had more then his share both those wayes: it it is worse Treason to raise Arms without his commission, or to fight against him, but it is the worst and highest Treason to take him, to cast him into prison, to debarre him of all earthly comforts, to allow him no servant or friend to converse with him, to attempt by dive • s wayes to murther him, this is somwhat more then Rebellion, and the highest pitch that Treason can mount to, except the Gallows.

Is there no other way to quench the thirst of Traytors but the blood Royall, and Loyall? my hope is better, though many true Subjects are ruined and undone in his M • j • sti • s name, yet let those who pretend to keep the Lawes (by robbing the people) looke into all Histories, and they shall finde that all Rebells have come to such fearfull ends, as may terrifie all such as are in the same condition as they were; they may consider that the King hath often off ed more in mercy, then then they could by any meanes have escaped by justice; for never was so good a King so badly used, never King did offer Subjects more (or the like gracious • ff • rs) and never did any ungracious Subj • cts so slight and abuse such gracious favours, which because they were so scornfully refus'd, they will hardly get them again with much intreaty.

Therefore looke what you have done Rebells, you have (by murder) halfe unman'd a Kingdome; for there is left at the most but one Male for 5 Females; and halfe those
men are old, blinde, lame, or made Beggers by you or your good meanes, as you have brought death with the sword, so you have caused dearth by famine and scarcity, which will bring diseases; the spoyles which you have made in 3 Kingdomes will not, cannot be repaired in 50 yeares. Turne and repent, the King is mercifull on Land, and the Navy blocks you in by Sea; so that Rebells shall shortly have no safe staying here without submission, nor any fleeing hence without destruction.

The Parliament made a selfe-denying Ordinance, which was, that no places of Office or profit which any of them (of either House) had by any Vote, Order, Grant, Gift or purchase, of goods, or Lands, that none of these, or any Interests of their owne (either generall or perticuler) should be any impediment, or Let to hinder a personall Treaty with his Maj sty; and now there are none in the Houses but such men as have places, Offices, and profits, who do oppose a personall Treaty, for feare they should be forc'd to su • render, and be outed of their misgotten gaines: as a Master of the Chanceries place is 3000. l. a yeare: A postmasters place of England worth 3000. l. a yeare, another hath some Office in the Custome-house, or some are Auditors for his Majewies Revenues, some Committeemen, and (omnium gatherum) the Offices and places of value to some of them thousands, and to the meanest of them hundreds of pounds, per annum.

These men are the strongest, and prevailing party in the House, or Houses, the chiefe of them being the Lord Say, and the wisest the Earle of Pembroke, Vaine, Mildmay, Ma • tin, Prideaux, Challoner, and consequently all the pack of • h • m who are nominated to treat (upon the Even or Vigill) of Saint never come whose names are as followeth, Earles of Northumberland, Suffolke, Kent, Stamford, Lincolne, (Pembroke, and Say before named) these are the wealthiest and most politique of the House of Peeres, who are picked out of the whole bunch to be Treaters.

For the House of Commons, they have cul'd out and appointed
these following birds of the like kind, (v • z) Sir Walter Earle, Sir Hairebraine (or Harbottle Grimstone) Sir William Lewis, Sir John Potts, Sir Robert Onslow, Sir Gilbert Gerard, Saint Robert Harly, Mr. Prideaux, Mr. Swinfen, Mr. Maynard, Mr. Wheeler, Mr. Lisle, Mr. Perpoynt, cum multis aliis.

These are the names of some of the Treaters, divers of whom, went to tamper with the Common Counsell of the City, and finding the Citizens (for the most and better part) very much given to Loyalty to their Soveraigne, and to a personall Treaty with his Majesty (which consequently will be the City and Kingdomes peace) which liking and good inclination in the Cit • zens did not rellish well in pallates of the Parliament men there present, who (to invade and shuffle of a Treaty for ever) began to make some mention of time, and place, when, and where this long lookt for, wish • for, and often promised Treaty should, or shall be: thus in the scales of Ballance, of quando and ubi is to be weighed, the happinesse or infelicity of our Church, of our King, of out Lawes, Lives, Liberties, and Freedome.

But we must never expect this happinesse as long as this mighty selfe-interested, and selfe-partiall party (I might have said selfe-guilty too) are so prevalent and powerfull that they can, and do overpower all the best affected in both the Houses; for you must understand there are many amongst them who doe love the King and the Kingdomes Peace, who would be glad to be at home in quiet; but these men are used but as younger Brothers, they have received no portions, they do sit in the Houses onely to fill up the seates, and as the figure of 1 with a Cypher added to it doth make the number 10; so the Grandees (or Bashawes) though they are the fewer in • mber, yet they are the stronger and most powerfull by fo ce and usurpation, and withall are very loath and unwill • g to let go their hold fast of what they have, or out of fe e, shame, and selfe guiltinesse for their perfidiousnesse to their King, and breach of
trust to those persons and places for whom they were intrusted; for these considerations, they (by the addition of the Cyphers) do seeme to be the whole number of both the Houses, and these are they that never will, nor never dare give a cordiall consent to a Pe • sonall Treaty; nay, though they had sworne they would have one, and prefixed whe • e and when, yet no man of sense or reason will believe them; for now they have another feat or knack out of the budget of the reverend Hocus Pocus, which is that great numbers of hands are gathered, and to be gathered from many carelesse Ignorants, desperate factionists, blinde zealous Seperatists, Sect • rious and godlesse Atheists, (besides cut throat Farfaxians) these are all incited and invited to bring in a Petition to the House of Commons against a personall Treaty, the said Petition (being penned by some of the wittiest of the wickedest of the Members) is shortly to be presented, and (no doubt) wilbe graciously received and accepted by the most high and most mighty amongst the State Rebells, and this wilbe one of the flim flams that shall uphold their tottering greatnesse, and cast down all hope of a personall Treaty with his Majesty.

And surely it is not impertinent, or much out of the way of Loyalty to ask or be a little inquisitive whether the King be in health or sick, or alive or dead; howsoever we can neither heare from him, or have admittance to see him, or send, or receive any thing to or from him (this is harder usage then ever any Rogue or Traytor suffred) besides we have not heard of him a great while; and it is too well knowne that he hath not one friend to a • tend him, nor any one that loves him can be suffred to come nere him; his life hath beene attempted to be taken away by the two damnable, and speeding meanes of Pistol and Poyson, which though (by the mercy and favour of God) he hath happily escaped; yet is he in dayly and hourly danger to be murdred by machinatious, assassinations, and divilish practises; his Royall Person is immured under as hard, as close, and as Traytorous a restraint as ever he was (if he be living) and
the same Villaines that kept him close do keepe him still; and his good God (in whom he puts his whole trust and confidence) as he hath with his Mighty providence and power defended him, so he will (in his owne good time) as he ha • h comforted him in all his afflictions, likewise give him deliverance (by his Almighty grace and favour) out of all his trou • les: And to conclude this point, it is the bounden duty of all loyall Subjects to pray for his M • jesties life, honour, and safety, and to do their best endeavours for h • s freedome, and a Personall Treaty whereby this Kingdome may be blest with Peace and Tranquility.

If the Cit zens of London do love his Majesty, their own Peace and the Kingdom • s, Let them not suffer the Trained Bands to guard a kennell of Traytors every day; is it not a wonder that those Souldiers (under a pretence of se ving the King) do every day and night lye in wait to take them, and violently hale and drag them to Prison? in which doings they are worse then the Hangman; for he (by Law) torments or executes none but Malefactors, Traytors, Thieves, and Murderers; but these Trained band men doe molest and trouble none but such as are true Subj • cts to his Majesty, or such as are suspected to feare God, in honouring and serving the King; therefore it were good that these men would give over this base kinde of guarding and defending of his Majesties worst and dispightful enemies, and also that they would desist (or be more sparing) in the doing continuall mischiefe to his friends; for the Proverb saith, Love me, and love my Dog.

p.hi: To doe as we should be done unto, is an excellent rule from the most excellent Scholemaster; now if all those Miscreant Recreants, would but take into their cursed considerations, what they have done to the King, and how they have dealt with him, and let them then speake truely whether any of them would be contented to be unjustly (by his own servants) throwne out of his inheritance of goods, lands, possessions, treasure, and liberty, to be deprived of the comfort and company of wife, children, friend, houshold seruant to attend, Phisition for the bodies preserving, or D • vine for the soules solace; to haue his name blur'd with calumnious and bitter slanders, to be libelled against and reviled, and to be restrain • d from writing or speaking in his owne defence. Shew me the man that hath suff • ed this much, and thrice as much more; yet that man is as much inferiour to King Charles in his sufferings, as beneath him in Royalty of Birth, Birthright, Dignity, Piery, Constancy, Christian Patience, Invincible Fortitude, and most Heroick Mag •• nimity.
